FIGURE.P: 1 Head from Herculaneum; whether Jupiter Tonans, or Venus of Paphos, doubted.
2 The Foot, with the Joes entire, of Juno Lucina.
3 The Hand of the Apollo of Delphos.
4 The Calf of the left Leg of the Infant Hercules.

DIV1.P: As it is Acted at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane.

Q.L: Be rich in antient Brass, tho' not in Gold,
And keep his Lares tho' his House be sold;
To headless Phoebe his fair Bride postpone,
Honour a Syrian Prince above his own:
Lord of an Otho, if I vouch it true;
Blst in one Niger, till he knows of two.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for R. FRANCKLIN, in Russel-street, Covent-Garden, 1752.

DIV1.HEAD: TO Francis Delaval, Esq;
DIV1.P:
WHEN I consider the long Intimacy that has subsisted between us, the Obligati∣ons I owe to your generous, disin∣terested Friendship, and the Protec∣tion and Encouragement I received both from you and your Brother, when Necessity listed me in the Ser∣vice of the Public; there is no Man to whom with equal Propriety and Pleasure I can address the fol∣lowing Work. It would be paying a bad Compliment to the Town were I to trouble you with an Apo∣logy for the Inconsiderableness of the Present. I thought it worthy their Attention, and consequently not beneath the Acceptance of my Friend.
With the Aid of a Love-plot I could have spun out the Piece to the Ex∣tent of five Acts; but besides that I wanted to confine the Eye to the single Object of my Satire, I declare myself a Rebel to this universal Ty∣rant, who, not contented with ex∣citing all that is pitiful or terrible in human Nature, has claim'd the Privilege of occasioning every Thing that is ridiculous or contemptible in it; and thus from the abject Sub∣mission of our dramatic Poets is both Tragedy and Comedy subjected to the Power of Love. It may be thought presumptuous in me to have digni∣fy'd so short a Performance with the Name of a Comedy; but when my Reasons why it cannot be call'd a Farce are consider'd, the Critics must indulge me with the Use of that Title; at least, till they can furnish me with a better. As the Follies and Absurdities of Men are the sole
Objects of Comedy so the Powers of the Imagination (Plot and Incident excepted) are in this kind of Writing greatly restrain'd. No unnatural As∣semblages, no Creatures of the Fancy can procure the Protection of the Comic Muse; Men and Things must appear as they are. To Farce greater Liberties are permitted. I look upon Farce to hold the same Rank in the Drama, that Burlesque does in other Poetry. It is employ'd either in debasing lofty Subjects▪ or in raising humble Ones▪ Of the two Kinds we have Examples in the Tom Thumb of Mr. F—, and a Travesty of the Ulysses, where Penelope keeps an Alehouse, Telemachus is a Tapster, and the Heroe a recruiting Serjeant. In both these Instances you see Nature is re∣versed; but as I flatter myself in the following Sheets her Steps have been trod with an indeviating Sim∣plicity, give me Leave to hope, that
tho' I have not attain'd the Togata, yet I have reach'd the Tabernaria of the Romans. I once intended to have thrown into this Address the Con∣tents of many of our Conversations on the Subject of Comedy; for in whatever Dissipations the World may suppose our Days to have been con∣sumed, many, many Hours have been consecrated to other Subjects than generally employ the Gay and the Giddy. I hope the present Oc∣casion will demonstrate that Pleasure has not been always my Pursuit; and unless I am greatly mistaken it will soon be discover'd that, join'd to the acknowledged best Heart in the World, Mr. Delaval has a Head capable of directing it. As I am now above the Reach of common Obliga∣tions, an Acknowledgment of these Qualities in the Person of a Man, who has honour'd me with his Friend∣ship, is the sole Cause of the Trouble
you now receive. Long has been our Union, may it never be divided till the fatal Stroke, that demolishes all sublunary Connections, shall reach One of us, which One will I hope be

DIV1.HEAD: THE PREFACE.
DIV1.P: I was always apprehensive that the Subject of the following Piece was too abstracted and singular for the Comprehension of a mix'd Assembly. Juno Lucina, Jupiter Tonans, Phi∣dias, Praxiteles, with the other Gentlemen and Ladies of Antiquity, were, I dare say, utterly unknown to my very good Friends of the Gal∣lery; nor to speak the Truth do I beleive they had many Acquaintances in the other Parts of the House. But tho' I despair of gratifying the Populum Tributim of the THEATRE, yet I flatter myself the Primores Populi will find me no disagreeable Companion in the Closet, et satis magnum Theatrum mihi estis.

I was neither prompted by a lucrative, nor an ambitious Motive to this Undertaking. My Design was to serve a Man, who had ever great Merit with his Friends, and to whom, on the score of some late Transactions, I think the Public vastly indebted. That my good Intenti∣ons for Mr. WORSDALE have proved successful, is intirely oweing to the Generosity and Huma∣nity of the Managers of Drury-Lane THEATRE;
they have given him a Benefit and are jointly entitled to my Thanks; but as to Mr. GARRICK, I have more personal Obligati∣ons. I take this Opportunity of assuring him, that I shall ever retain the most grateful Re∣membrance of his Assistance, Assiduity, and kind Concern▪ at the Birth, Progress, and un∣timely End of this my last and favourite Off∣spring.

The Objects of my Satire were such as I thought, whether they were consider'd in a moral, a political, or a ridiculous Light, deser∣ved the Notice of the Comic Muse. I was de∣termined to brand those Goths in Science, who had prostituted the useful Study of Antiquity to trifling superficial Purposes; who had blasted the Progress of the elegant Arts amongst us, by unpardonable Frauds and absurd Prejudices; and who had corrupted the Minds and Morals of our Youth, by persuading them that what only serves to illustrate Literature was true Learning, and active Idleness real Business. How far this End has been obtain'd is now in the following Sheets more generally submitted to the Public.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
And spoken by him in the Character of an Auctioneer.

LG.L: BEfore this Court I PETER PUFF appear,
A Briton born▪ and bed an Auctioneer;
Who f r myself, and eke a hundred others,
My useful▪ honest, learned, bawling Brothers,
Humility and Fear implore ye,
To our present, desp'rate Case before ye.—
'is this Night a certain Wag intends
To laugh at us, our Calling, and our Friends:
I Lords and Ladies, and such dinty Folks,
Are ur'd Auction▪hunting by his Jokes;
Should this odd Doctrine spread throughout the Land,
Before you buy, be sure o understand,
Oh think on us what various Ills will flow,
When great Ones only purchase—what they know.
Why laugh at ST? It is a harmless Fashion,
And quite subdues each detrimental Passion;
T Fair ones Hearts will ne'er incline to Man,
While thus they rage for—China and Japan.
The Virtuoso too, and Connoisseur,
Are ever decert delicate and pure;
The smallest Hair their looser Thoughts might hold,
Just warm when Single, and when Married cold:
Their Blood at Sight of Beauty gently flows;
Their Venus must e old, and want a Nose!
No am'rous Passion with deep Knowledge thrives;
'Tis the oml t indeed of all our Wives!
Tis said Virtu to such a Heighth is grown,
All Artists are encourag'd—but our own.
Be not deceiv'd, I here declare on Oath,
I never yet sold Goods of foreign Growth:
Ne'er sent Commissions out to Greece or Rome;
My best Antiquities are made at Home.
I've Romans, Greeks, Italians near at hand,
True Britons all—and living in the Strand.
I ne'er for Trinkets rack my Pericranium,
They furnish out my Room from Herculaneum.
But hush—
Should it be known that English are employ'd,
Our Manufacture is at once destroy'd;
No matter what our Countrymen deserve,
They'll thrive as Antients, but as Moderns starve—
If we should fall—to you it will be owing;
Farewell to Arts—they're going, going, going;
The fatal Hammer's in your Hand, oh Town!
Then set Us up—and knock the POET down.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. I.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter CARMINE, follow'd by the BOY.

SP.SPEAKER: CARMINE.
SP.P: LAY these Colours in the Window, by the Pallet. Any Visitors or Messages?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P:
'Squire Felltree has been here, and insists upon Mis Racket's Pictures being imme∣diately
finish'd, and carried Home—as to his Wife and Children, he says, you may take your own Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Well—

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Here has been a Message too, from my Lady Pen—I can't remember her Name, but 'tis upon the Slate; she desires to know if you would be at Home about Noon.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Fetch it. [Exit Boy.

Was the Whole of our Profession confined to the meer Business of it, the Employment would be pleasing as well as profitable; but as Matters are now managed, the Art is the last Thing to be regarded. Family Connections, private Recommendations, and an easy, genteel Method of flattering, is to supply the Delicacy of a Guido, the Colouring of a Reubens, and the Design of a Raphael—all their Qualities cen∣tring in one Man, without the first Requisites, would be useless, and with these not one of them is necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P:
Let's see—Oh! Lady Pentweazel, from Blowbladder-Street—Admit her by all Means; and if Puff or Varnish should come, I am at Home. [Exit Boy. Lady Pentweazel! ha! ha! Now here's a Proof that Avarice is not the only, or last Passion old
Age is subject To—this superannuated Bel∣dame gapes for Flattery, like a Nest of unfledged Crows for Food; and with them too, gulps down every Thing that's offer'd her—no matter how Coarse; well, she shall be fed; I'll make her my introductory Key to the whole Bench of Aldermen.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Mr. Puff, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Let us be private. What have you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Two of Rembrant's etching by Scrape, in May's Buildings,; a paultry Affair, a poor ten Guinea Job; however, a small Game—you know the Proverb—what became of you Yesterday?

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: I was detain'd by Sir Positive Bubble. How went the Pictures? The Guido, what did that fetch?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: One hundred and thirty.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Hum! four Guineas the Frame, three the Painting; then we divide just one hundred and twenty-three.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Hold—not altogether so fast—Varnish had two Pieces for bidding against Squander, and Brush five, for bringing Sir Tawdry Trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Mighty well; look ye, Mr. Puff, if these People are eternally quarter'd upon us, I declare off, Sir; they eat up the Profit. There's that damn'd Brush—but you'll find him out. I have upon his old Plan given him Copies of all the Work I executed upon his Recommendation; and what was the Consequence? He clandestine∣ly sold the Copies, and I have all the Originals in my Lumber-Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Come, come, Carmine, you are no great Looser by that. Ah! that Lumber-Room! that Lumber-Room out of Repair, is the best condition'd Estate in the County of Middlesex. Why now there's your Susannah; it could not have produced you above twenty at most, and by the Addition of your Lumber-Room Dirt, and the salutary Application of the 'spaltham Pot, it became a Guido worth a hundred and thirty Pound; besides, in all Traffick of this Kind, there must be Combinations. Varnish and Brush are our Jackcalls, and it is but fair they should partake of the Prey. Courage, my Boy! never fear; Praise be to Folly and Fashion, there are, in this Town, Dupes enough to gra∣tify the Avarice of us all.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P:
Mr. Puff, you are ignorant▪ and scurrilous, and very impertinent, Mr. Puff; and, Mr. Puff, I have a strange Mind to leave you to yourselves, and then see what a Hand you would make of it—Sir, if I do now and
then add some Tincts of Antiquity to my Pictures, I do it in Condescension to the Foible of the World; for, Sir, Age, Age, Sir, is all my Pictures want to render 'em as good Pieces as the Masters for whom they are taken; and let me tell you, Sir, he that took my Susannah for a Guido, gave no mighty Proofs of his Ig∣norance, Mr. Puff.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Why, thou Post-Painter, thou Dauber, thou execrable White-washer, thou—Sirrah, have you so soon forgot the wretched State, from whence I drag'd you. The first Time I set Eyes on you, Rascal! what was your Oc∣cupation then? Scribbling, in scarce legible Let∣ters, Coffee, Tea and Chocolate on a Bawdy-House Window in Goodman's Fields.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: The Meanness of my Original de∣monstrates the Greatness of my Genius.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Genius! Here's a Dog. Pray, how high did your Genius soar? To the daubing diabolical Angels for Alehouses, Dogs with Chains for Tanners-yards, Rounds of Beef and roasted Pigs for Porridge Island.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Hannibal Scratchi did the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: From that contemptible State did not I raise you to the Cat and Fiddle in Petticoat-Lane; the Goose and Gridiron in Paul's-Church∣yard; the first live Things you ever drew, Dog?

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Pox take your Memory. Well, but, Mr. Puff—you are so—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Nor did I quit you then; who, Sirrah, recommended you to Prim Stiff, the Mercer upon Ludgate-hill; how came you to draw the Queen there? (loud Knocks at the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Mr. Puff, for Heaven's Sake; Dear Sir, you are so warm, we shall be blown—

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Sir, my Lady Pen—

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Send her to the—show her up Stairs. Dear Puff—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Oh! Sir, I can be calm; I only wanted to let you see I had not forgot, tho' perhaps you may.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Sir, you are very obliging. Well, but now as all is over, if you will retreat a small Time—Lady Pentweazel sits for her Picture, and she's—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: I have some Business at next Door. I suppose in half an Hours Time—

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: I shall be at Leisure. Dear Puff—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Dear Carmine—(Exit Puff.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Son of a Whore—Boy, shew the Lady up Stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Fine Pieces!—very likely Pieces! and, indeed, all alike; Hum! Lady Fussock—and ha! ha! ha! Lady Glumstead, by all
that's ugly—Pray now, Mr. Carmine, how do you Limners contrive to overlook the Ugli∣ness, and yet preserve the Likeness.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: The Art, Madam, may be convey'd in two Words; where Nature has been severe, we soften; where she has been kind, we ag∣gravate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Very ingenus, and very kind truly. Well, good Sir, I bring you a Subject that will demand the Whole of the first Part of your Skill; and, if you are at Leisure, you may begin di∣rectly.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Your Ladyship is here a little un∣grateful to Nature, and cruel to yourself; even Lady Pentweazel's Enemies (if such there be) must allow she is a fine Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh! your Servant, good Sir. Why I have had my Day, Mr. Carmine; I have had my Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: And have still, Madam. The only Difference I shall make between what you were, and what you are, will be no more than what Rubens has distinguish'd between Mary de Medicis a Virgin, and a Regent.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Mr. Carmine, I vow you are a very judicious Person. I was always said to be like that Family. When my Piece was first done, the Limner did me after Venus de Medicis, which I suppose might be one of Mary's Sisters▪ but Things must change; to be sitting for my
Picture at this Time of Day; ha! ha!—but my Daughter Sukey, you must know, is just married to Mr. Deputy Dripping, of Candle∣wick-Ward, and would not be said nay; so it is not so much for the Beauty, as the Similitude. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: True, Madam; ha! ha! but if I hit the Likenefs, I must preserve the Beauty.—Will your Ladyship be seated. (She sits)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I have heard, good Sir, that every Body has a more betterer, and more worserer Side of the Face than the other—now which will you chuse?

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: The right Side, Madam—the left—now if you please the full—Your Ladyship's Countenance is so exactly proportion'd that I must have it all, no Feature can be spared.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: When you come to the Eyes, Mr. Carmine, let me know, that I may call up a Look.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Mighty well, Madam—Your Face a little to the Left; nearer me—your Head more up—Shoulders back—and Chest forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Bless me, Mr. Carmine, don't mind my Shape this Bout; for I'm only in Jumps—shall I send for my Tabbys.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P:
No, Madam, we'll supply that for the present—your Ladyship was just now mentioning a Daughter—is she—your
Face a little more towards me—Is she the sole Inheritor of her Mother's Beauty? Or—have you—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: That? ha! ha! ha!—why that's my youngest of all, except Caleb. I have had, Mr. Carmine, live, born, and christen'd—stay—don't let me lye now—One—Two—Three—Four—Five—then I lay fallow—but the Year after I had Twins—they came in Mr. Pentweazel's Sheriffialty; then Roger, then Robin, then Reuben—in short, I have had twenty as fine Babes, as ever trod in Shoe of Leather.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Upon my Word, Madam, your Ladyship is an admirable Member of the Com∣monwealth; 'tis a thousand Pities that, like the Romans, we have not some Honours to reward such distinguish'd Merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Mr. Carmine, if breeding amongst Christians was as much encouraged as amongst Dogs and Horses, we need not be making Laws to let in a Parcel of outlandish Locusts to eat us all up.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: I am told, Madam, that a Bill for some such good Purpose is about to pass, and that we begin now to have almost as much Regard for the Propagation of the Species, as the Preservation of the Game in these Kingdoms.—Now, Madam, I am come to the Eyes—oh!—that Look, that, that, I must despair of imitating.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh! oh! good Sir, have you found out that? Why all my Family by the Mother's Side were famous for their Eyes: I have a great Aunt amongst the Beauties at Windsor; she has a Sister at Hampton-Court, a perdigious fine Woman—she had but one Eye indeed, but that was a Piercer; that one Eye got her three Husbands—we were call'd the gimlet▪ey'd Family Oh, Mr. Carmine; you need not mind these Heats in my Face; they always discharge themselves about Christmas—my true Carnation is not seen in my Countenance. That's Carnation! Here's your Flesh and Blood! (shewing her Arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Delicate indeed! finely turn'd, and of a charming Colour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And yet it has been employ'd enough to spoil the best Hand and Arm in the World.—Even before Marriage never idle; none of your galloping, gossoping, Ranelagh Romps, like the forward Minxes of the present Age. I was always employ'd either in painting your Lanskips, playing upon the Haspicols, ma∣king Paste, or something or other—All our Family had a Geno; and then I sung! Every Body said I had a monstrous fine Voice for Musick.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: That may be discern'd by your La∣dyship's Tones in Conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Tones—you are right, Mr. Carmine; that was Mr. Purcel's Word. Miss Molly Gris∣kin,
says he, (my Maiden Name) you have Tones.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: As your Ladyship has preserved every Thing else so well, I dare swear you have not lost your Voice. Will you favour me with an Air?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh! Sir, you are so polite that it's impossible—But I have none of your new Playhouse Songs—I can give you one that was made on myself by Lawrence Lutestring a Neighbour's Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: What you please, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: As I was a walk by the Side of a River,
I met a young Damsel so charming and clever;
Her Voice to please it could not fail,
SP.P: Bless me! I have such a Cough! but there are Tones.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Inimitable ones.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But, Mr. Carmine, you Limners are all ingenus Men—you sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: A Ballad or so, Madam; Musick is a Sister Art; and it would be a little unnatural not to cultivate an Acquaintance there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Why truly we ought not to be asha∣med of our Relations, unless they are poor, and then you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Alderman Pentweazel, and Mr. Puff.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Oh! he was to call upon me; we go to the Auction. Desire him to walk up—Mr. Pentweazel, you must know, went this Morning to meet Caleb, my youngest Boy, at the Bull and Gae. The Child has been two Years and three Quarters at School with Doctor Jerk near Doncaster, and comes to Day by the York Waggon; for it has always been my Maxum, Mr. Carmine, to give my Children Learning enough; for, as the old Saying is,
When House and Land are gone and spent,
Then Learning is most excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Your Ladyship is quite right. Too much Money cannot be employ'd in so mate∣rial an Article.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Nay the Cost is but small▪ but poor ten Pounds a Year for Head, Back, Books, Bed and Belly; and they say the Children are all wonderful Latiners, and come up, lack a Day, they come up as fat as Pigs—Oh! here they are; odds me! he's a Thumper. You see, Mr. Carmine, I breed no Starvelings. Come hither, Child. Mind your Haviours. Where's your best Bow? Turn out your Toes. One would think the Boy had learnt to dance of his Father. I'm sure my Family were none so awkward. There was my Brother George, a perfect Picture of a Man; he danced, lud! But come, all in good Time—Hold up thy Head, Caleb.

SP.SPEAKER: Ald.
SP.P: Prythee, sweet Honey, let the Child alone. His Master says he comes on wonder∣ful in his Learning; and as to your Bows and your Congees, never fear, he'll learn them fast enough at Home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Lack a Day! Well said We now—if he does, I know who must teach him. Well, Child, and dost remember me? Hey? Who am I?

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: Anon?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Dost know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: Yes; you be Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Nay, the Boy had always a good Memory; and what hast learn'd, Caleb, hey?

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: I be got into Aesop's Fables, and can say all As in praesenti by Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Upon my Word that's more than ever thy Father could.

SP.SPEAKER: Ald.
SP.P: Nay, nay, no Time has been lost; I question'd the Lad as we came along; I ask'd him himself—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Well, well; speak when you are spoke to, Mr. Alderman. How often must I—Well, Caleb, and hadst a good deal of Company in the Waggon up, hey, Boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: O Law! Powers of Company, Mo∣ther. There was Lord Gorman's fat Cook, a Blackamoor Drumming Man, two Actor Peo∣ple, a recruiting Serjeant, a Monkey and I.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Upon my Word, a pretty Parcel.

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: Yes indeed; but the—the fat Cook got drunk at Coventry, and so fell out at the Tail of the Waggon; so we left she behind. The next Day the Serjeant run away with the Shew∣man's Wife the t'other two went after; so only the Monkey and I came to Town together.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Upon my Word, the young Gentle∣man gives a good Account of his Travels.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Mr. Carmine, he's all over the Blood of the Griskins. I warrant the Child will make his Way. Go, Caleb, go and look at them pretty Paintings—Now, Mr. Carmine, let us see if my good Man can find me out.

SP.SPEAKER: Ald.
SP.P: Lack a Day; well, I profess they are all so handsome that I am puzzled to know which is thine, Chuck.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: I am surprized at your Want of Discern∣ment, Mr. Alderman; but the Possession of a Jewel destroys it's Value with the Wearer; now to me it seems impossible to err; and tho' Mr. Carmine is generally successful, in this Instance he is par∣ticularly happy. Where can you meet with that Mixture of Fire and Softness, but in the Eyes of Lady Pentweazel?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: h, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: That Clearness and Delicacy of Com∣plexion, with that Flow of Ruddiness and Health.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Sir! Sir! Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P:
That Fall of Shoulders, Turn of Neck,
set on Head, full Chest, taper Waste, Plump—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Spare me, sweet Sir—You see, Mr. Pentweaxel, other People can find out my Charms, tho' you overlook them—Well, I profess, Sir, you are a Gentleman of great Dis∣cernment; and if Business should bring you into the City, for alas! what Pleasure can bring a Man of your refined Taste there!—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Oh! Maam!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I say, Sir, if such an Accident should happen, and Blowbladder-street has any Charms—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Oh! Maam! Maam! Maam! Maam!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: It is not impossible but we may re∣ceive you, tho' not equal to your Merits—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Maam!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Yet in such a Manner as to shew our Sense of them; Sir, I'm your very obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Your Ladyship's most—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Not a Step.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Maam—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Sir—Mr. Alderman, your Bow to the Gentleman. The very finest.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Maam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Sir—Your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Your devoted.—(Exit. Ald. & Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Ha! ha! Well said, Puff; what a Ca∣lamity hast thou drawn upon the Knight? Thou hast so tickled the Vanity of the Harradan, that the poor Helpmate will experience a double Portion of her Contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Rot them.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Come, Puff; a matrimonial Assistant to a rich Alderman is no contemptible Em∣ployment.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Ay, if it were a Sine Cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: No, that you must not expect; but unless I am greatly mistaken in the Language of the Eyes, her Ladyship's were address'd to you with most persuasive Tenderness.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Well, of that hereafter—But to our Business. The Auction is about be∣ginning; and I have promised to meet Sir David Dusledorpe, Sir Positive Bubble, and Lord Dupe, to examine the Pictures, and fix on those for which they are to bid—but since, we have settled the German Plan; so Varnish or Brush must attend them.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm
SP.P: Oh! by all Means pursue that. You have no Conception how dear the foreign Ac∣cent is to your true Virtuoso; it announces Taste, Knowledge, Veracity, and in short every Thing.—But can you enough disguise the Turn of your Face, and Tone of your Voice? A Disco∣very of Mr. Puff in Mynheer Groningen blasts us at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Never fear me. I wish you may have equal Success in the Part of Canto.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P:
Pho! mine's a Trifle. A Man must have very slender Abilities indeed who can't for ten Minutes imitate a Language and Deport∣ment
that he had been Witness to for ten Years.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: But you must get their Tones, their Tones; 'tis easy enoug. Come, hand up here that there Corregio; an inimitable Piece, Gen∣tlemen and Ladies; the very best Work of the best Master, Subject agreeable, highly finish'd and well preserved; a Seat for the Ladies; hand it to Sir Positive; a going for fifty, speak or it's gone for fifty; Joy to your Ladyship; come, the next. But remember, let your Bob be bushy, and your Bow low.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Enough, enough; we are Strangers to each other, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Absolute. Oh, but what Pictures of yours are in the Sale?

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: There's my holy Family by Raphael; the Marriage in Canaan by Reuben Rouge; Tom Jackson's Teniers; and for Busts, Taylor's Head without a Nose, from Herculaneum.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Are the antique Seals come Home?

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: No—but they will be finish'd by next Week.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: You must take Care of Novice's Col∣lection of Medals—he'll want them by the End of the Month.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm▪
SP.P: The Coins of the first Emperors are now steeping in Copperas; and I have an Otho, a Galba, a Nero, and two Domitians reaking from the Dunghill.—The rest we can have from Doctor Mummy; a never failing Chap, you know▪

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Yours, Sir—a troublesome Fellow this—confounded Memory—useful tho'—Rounds of Beef and roasted Pigs!—must get rid of him—ay, but when?—Why when?—when I have gain'd my Point. But how, how then—? Oh, then it does not signify two Pence. (Exeunt.

DIV2.TRAILER: The End of the FIRST ACT.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. II.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Puff as Monsieur Baron de Groningen, Carmine as Canto, and Brush.

SP.SPEAKER: CANTO.
SP.P: COME, bustle, bustle. Brush, you intro∣duce Puff. Puff, how are you in your German?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: I canno speak for Englandt, but I can mak understandt very mightily. Will that do?—

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P:
To a Hair. Remember you are come hither to purchase Pictures for the Elector of Bavaria. Carmine, you must clap Lord
Dupe's Coat of Arms on that half Length of E∣rasmus; I have sold it him, as his great Grand∣father's third Brother, for fifty Guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: It shall be done.—Be it my Pro∣vince to establish the Baron's Reputation as a Connoisseur;—Brush has seen you abroad at the Court of the Reigning Prince of Blantin.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Yes; I was do Business mightily for Prince Blantin.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: Your Portraits go first, Carmine. Novice, Sir Positive Bubble, Jack Squander, Lord Dupe, and Mordecai Lazarus the Jew Broker, have appointed me to examine with them the History Pieces.—Which are most likely to stick?

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: Here's a List.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: Hush, hide the Erasmus; I hear the Company on the Stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Mr. Brush, I am your devoted Ser∣vant. You have procured my Ancestor?

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: It is in my Possession, my Lord; and I have the Honour to assure your Lordship, that the family Features are very discernable; and, allowing for the Difference of Dress, there's a strong Likeness between you and your Pre∣decessor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir, you have obliged me. All these you have mark'd in the Catalogue are Originals?

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: Undoubted; but, my Lord, you need not depend solely on my Judgment; here's Mynheer Baron de Groningen, who is come hi∣ther to survey, and purchase for the Elector of Bavaria; an indisputable Connoisseur; his bid∣ding will be a Direction for your Lordship. 'Tis a thousand Pities that any of these Masters should quit England; they were conducted hi∣ther at an immense Expence; and if they now leave us, what will it be but a publick Declara∣tion, that all Taste, and liberal Knowledge is vanish'd from amongst us?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir—leave the support of the national Credit to my Care. Could you intro∣duce me to Mynheer?—Does he speak English?

SP.SPEAKER: Brush
SP.P: Not fluently, but so as to be under∣stood. Mynheer, Lord Dupe—the Patron of Arts, the Petronius for Taste, and for well-timed Generosity, the Leo—and the Mecenas—of the present Age, desires to know you?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Sir, you honour me very mightily. I was hear of Lord Dupes in Hollandt. I was tell he was one Delatant, one Curieuse, one Preceus of this Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: The Dutch are an obliging, civilized, well bred, pretty Kind of People; but, pray Sir, what occasions us the Honour of a Visit from you?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: I was come to bid for Paints for de Elector of Bavaria.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Are there any here that deserves your Attention?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Oh, there are good Pieces; but dare is one I likes mightily; the off Sky, and home Track is fine, and the Maister is in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What is the Subject?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Dat I know not; vat I minds, vat you call the Draws and the Colors.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Mr. Canto, what is the Subject;

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: It is, my Lord, St. Anthony of Padua exorcizing the Devil out of a Ram-Cat; it has a Companion somewhere—oh! here, which is the same Saint in a Wilderness, reading his Breviary by the Light of a Glow-worm.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: Invaluable Pictures both! and will match your Lordship's Corregio in the Saloon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I'll have them. What Pictures are those, Mr. Canto?

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: They are not in the Sale; but I fancy I could procure them for your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: This, I presume, might have been a Landskip; but the Water, and the Men, and the Trees, and the Dogs, and the Ducks, and the Pigs, they are all obliterated, all gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: An indisputable Mark of it's Anti∣quity; it's very Merit; besides, a little Varnish will fetch the Figures again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Set it down for me—the next.

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P:
That is a Moses in the Bulrushes. The
blended Joy and Grief in the Figure of the Sister in the Corner, the Distress and Anxiety of the Mother here, and the Beauty and Benevolence of Pharah's Daughter, are Circumstances hap∣pily imagined and boldly express'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: Lack a Day, 'tis but a modern Performance; the Master is alive, and an Eng∣lishman.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh, then I would not give it House-Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Here is a pretty Piece, I find stick up here in de Corner; I was see in Hollands, at Loo, a Piece mighty like; there was little Mices, that was nibble, nibble, nibble, upon vat you call Frumage, and little Shurels all with brush Tails, ran up de Trees; and there was great Things, vat you call—Pshaw, that have long Bearts, and cry Ba.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: What, Goats?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Ay, dat was de Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I should think, by the Cheese, and the Goats, Mynheer, yours was a Welch Piece, instead of a Dutch?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Ah, 'twas goot Piece. I wish to my Heart, Lord Dupes was have that Piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Novice.
SP.P: Where's Mr. Brush? My dear Brush, am I too late?

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: In pretty good Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: May I lose my Otho, or be tumbled from my Phaeton the first Time I jehup my Sorels, if I have not made more haste than a young Surgeon to his first Labour. But, the Lots, the Lots, my dear Brush, what are they? I'm upon the Rack of Impatience till I see them, and in a Feaver of Desire till I possess them.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: Mr. Canto, the Gentleman would be glad to see the Busts, Medals, and precious Reliques, of Greece and antient Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: Perhaps, Sir, we may show him something of greater Antiquity.—Bring them forward.—The first Lot consists of a Hand without an Arm, the first Joint of the Fore-fin∣ger gone, supposed to be a Limb of the Apollo Delphos.—The second, half a Foot, with the Toes entire, of the Juno Lucina. The third, the Caduceus of the Mercurius infernalis.—The fourth, the Calf of the left Leg of the Infant Hercules—all indisputable Antiques, and of the Memphian Marble.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Let me see Juno's half Foot. All the Toes entire?

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: All.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Here is a little swelt by this Toe, that looks bad Proportion.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Hey, hey.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: What's dat?

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: That! Pshaw! that! Why that's on∣ly a Corn.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Corn! dat was extream natural; dat is fine; the Maister is in it.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Very fine! Invaluable!

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Where is de Hercules' Calf? Upon my Word 'tis a very large Calf; big, big, big, all de Way up, all de Way down.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I believe this Hercules was an Irish Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: But where are your Busts? Here, here, Gentlemen, here's a Curiosity; a Medal of Oriuna; got for me by Doctor Mummy; the only one in the visible World; there may be some under Ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Fine indeed! Will you permit me to taste it? It has the Relish. (All taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: The Relish! Zooks it cost me a hun∣dred Guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: By gar, it is a dear Bit tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: So you may think; but three times the Money should not purchase it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, whose Bust is it that dig∣nifies this Coin?

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: The Empress Oriuna, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And who, Sir, might she be? I don't recollect to have heard of the Lady before.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P:
She, my Lord? Oh, she was a kind of a what d'ye call 'em—a sort of a Queen
or Wife, or something or other to somebody, that liv'd a damn'd while ago—Mummy told me the whole Story; but before gad I've forgot it. But come, the Busts.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: Bring forward the Head from Hercu∣laneum. Now, Gentlemen, here is a Jewel.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ay, ay, let's see.

SP.SPEAKER: Carm.
SP.P: 'Tis not intire tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: So much the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: Right, Sir—the very Mutilati∣ons of this Piece are worth all the most perfect Performances of modern Artists.—Now, Gentlemen, here's a Touchstone for your Taste!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Great! great indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: Great? Amazing! divine! oh, let me embrace the dear dismember'd Bust! a little far∣ther off. I'm ravish'd! I'm transported! What an Attitude? But then the Locks! How I adore the Simplicity of the Antients! How unlike the present, priggish, prick-eard Puppies! How grace∣fully they fall all adown the Cheek! so decent, and so grave, and—who the Devil do you think it is, Brush? Is it a Man, or a Woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: The Connoisseurs differ. Some will have it to be the Jupiter Tonans of Phidias, and others the Venus of Paphos from Praxiteles; but I don't think it fierce enough for the first, nor handsome enough for the last.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: Yes, handsome enough.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Very handsome, handsome enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: Not quite—therefore I am inclined to join with Signor Julio de Pampedillo, who in a Treatise, dedicated to the King of the two Sicilies, calls it the Serapis of the Aegyptians, and supposes it to have been fabricated about e∣leven hundred and three Years before the Mo∣saick Account of the Creation.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: Prodigious! and I dare swear true.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Oh! true, very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Upon my honour, 'tis a ver fine Bust; but where is de Nose?

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: The Nose; what care I for the Nose? Where is de Nose? Why, Sir, if it had a Nose, I would not give Six-pence for it.—How the Devil should we distinguish the Works of the Antients, if they were perfect?—The Nose indeed! Why I don't suppose now, but, bar∣ring the Nose, Rubiliac could cut as good a Head ev'ry whit.—Brush, who is this Man with his Nose? The Fellow should know some∣thing of something too; for he speaks broken English.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: It is Mynheer Groningen; a great Connoisseur in Painting.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: That may be; but as to Sculpture, I am his very humble Servant. A Man must know damn'd little of Statuary, that dislikes a Bust for want of a Nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P:
Right, Sir.—The Nose itself with∣out the Head, nay in another's Possession, would
be an Estate.—But here are behind, Gen∣tlemen and Ladies, an equestrian Statue of Marcus Aurelius without the Horse; and a compleat Statue of the Emperor Trajan, with only the Head and Legs missing; both from Herculaneum.—This Way, Gentlemen and Ladies.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lady Pentweazel, Alderman and Caleb.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Now, Mr. Pentweazel, let us have none of your Blowbladder Breeding. Remember you are at the Court-End of the Town. This is a Quality Auction.

SP.SPEAKER: Ald.
SP.P: Where of Course, nothing is sold that is unuseful.—I am tutor'd, sweet Honey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Caleb, keep behind, and don't be meddling. Sir,—(To Brush.)

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: Your Pleasure, Maam?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I should be glad you would inform me if there are any Lots of very fine old China. I find the Quality are grown infinitely fond of it; and I am willing to show the World that we in the City have Taste?

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: 'Tis a laudable Resolution, Maam; and, I dare say, Mr. Canto can supply—Bless me, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
That Boy, I suppose! Well, if the mischievous Brat has not broke a—and look
how he stands—Sirrah, Sirrah, did not I bid you not meddle—Leave sucking your Thumbs. What, I suppose you learnt this Trick of your Friend the Monkey in the Wag∣gon?

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: Indeed I did not go to do it, Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ald.
SP.P: Prythee, sweet Honey, don't be so pas∣sionate. What's done can't be undone. The Loss is not great; come, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Brush.
SP.P: Mr. Alderman is in the right. The Affair is a Trifle; but a twenty Guinea Job.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Twenty Guineas! You should have twenty of my Teeth as—

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: You mean if you had them—Your Ladyship does not know the Value of that Piece of China. It is the right old Japan of the pea green Kind. Lady Mandarin offer'd me, if I could match it, fourscore Guineas for the Pair.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: A fine Piece indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: 'Tis ver fine!

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: Indeed, Father, I did not break it. 'Twas crack'd in the Middle, and so fell a two in my Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: What, was it crack'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: Yes, indeed, Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: There, Gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
Maam, I would willingly set you right in this Affair; you don't seem acquainted with these Kind of Things; therefore, I have the
Honour to tell you that the Crack in the Middle is a Mark of it's Antiquity, and enhances it's Value; and these Gentlemen are, I dare say, of the same Opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Oh, intirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: You are all of a Gang, I think. A broken Piece of China better than a whole one!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Maam, I never dispute with a Lady; but this Gentleman has Taste; he is a Foreigner, and so can't be thought prejudiced; refer it to him; the Day grows late, and I want the Auc∣tion to begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ald.
SP.P: Sweet Honey, leave it to the Gentle∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Madam, I love to serve de Lady. 'Tis a ver fine Piece of China. I was see such ano∣ther Piece sell at Amsterdam for a hundred Du∣cats. 'Tis ver well worth twenty Guinea.

SP.SPEAKER: Caleb.
SP.P: Mother!—Father! Never stir if that Gentleman ben't the same that we see'd at the Painting Man's, that was so zivil to Mother, only he has got a black Wig on, and speaks out∣landish. I'll be fur enough if it en't a May∣game.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Hey! Let me die but the Boy's in the right. My Dear, as I'm alive Mr. Puff, that we saw at the Limner's. I told you he was a more cleverer Man than I ever saw. Caleb is right; some Matter of Merriment, I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: I wish it was. (Aside.) I no understand▪

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: So, Master Puff, you are caught (Aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord
SP.P: This is a most unfortunate old Lady.—Maam, you are here under another Mis∣take. This is Mynheer Baron de—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Mynheer Figs-end. Can't I believe my own Eyes? What, do you think, because we live in the City, we can't see.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: Fire me, my Lord, there may be more in this than we can guess. It's worth examining into. Come, Sir, if you are Mynheer, who the Devil knows you?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: I was know Maister Canto mightily.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: Mr. Canto, do you know this Baron?

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P: I see the Dog will be detected, and now is my Time to be even with him for his Rounds of Beef and roasting Pigs. (Aside.) I can't say I ever saw the Gentleman before.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: Oh, oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: The Fellow is an Impostor; a palpa∣ble Cheat. Sir, I think you came from the Rhine; pray, how should you like walking into the Thames?

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: Or what think you, my Lord? The Rascal complain'd but now that the Bust wanted a Nose; suppose we were to supply the Defici∣ency with his.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But Justice, Mr. Novice.

SP.SPEAKER: Canto.
SP.P:
Great Rascal indeed, Gentlemen! If Rogues of this Stamp get once a Footing in
these Assemblies, adieu to all moral Honesty. I think an Example should be made of him. But, were I to advise, he is a properer Subject for the Rabble to handle than the present Com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Away with him—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Hands off. If I must suffer, it shall not be singly. Here is the obsequious Mr. Brush, and the very courtly Mr. Canto, shall be the Partners of my Distress. Know then, we all are Rogues. If the taking Advantage of the Absurdities and Follies of Mankind can be call'd Roguery, I own I have been a Cheat, and I glory in it. But what Point will you Virtuosi, you Connoisseurs, gain by the Detection? Will not the publishing of our Crimes trumpet forth your Folly?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Matchless Impudence!

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: My noble Lord here, the Delatanti, the Curieu, the Precieu of this Nation, what infinite Glory will he acquire from this Story, that the Leo, the Maecenas, the Petronius, not∣withstanding his exquisite Taste, has been drawn in to purchase, at an immense Expence, a Cart∣load of—Rubbish.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Gentlemen and Ladies—I have the Honour to take my Leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Your Lordship's most obedient—When shall I send you your Corregio, your St. Anthony of Padua, your Ram Cat, my good Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Rascal. (Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: This won't do, Sir.—Tho' my Lord has not Spirit enough, damn me if I quit you. (Shutting the Door.)

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: What, my sprightly Squire! Pray fa∣vour me with a Sight of your Oriuna.—It has the Relish; an indisputable Antique; being a Bristol Farthing, coin'd by a Soap-Boiler to pay his Journeymen in the Scarcity of Cash, and purchased for two Pence of a travelling Tinker by, Sir, your humble Servant, Timothy

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: My Oriuna a Bristol Farthing!

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Most assuredly.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: I'll be revenged. (going)

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Stay, stay, and take your Bust, my sweet Squire; your Serapis. Two Heads, they say, are better than one; lay them together. But the Locks! How gracefully they fall all a∣down! so decent, and so—ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: Confound you.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Why, Sir, if it had a Nose, I would not give Sixpence for it—Pray, how many Years before the Creation was it fabricated, Squire?

SP.SPEAKER: Nov.
SP.P: I shall live to see you hang'd, you Dog. (Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Nay but, Squire; ha, ha, ha!—Now, Madam, to your Ladyship I come; to whose Discernment, aided by the Sagacity of your Son Caleb, I owe my Discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Ald.
SP.P: Look you, don't think to abuse my Lady. I am one of the—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Quorum—I know it, Mr. Alderman; but I mean to serve your Worship by humbling a little the Vanity of your Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Come along, Chuck. I'll not stay to hear the Rascality of the Fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Oh, my Lady Pentweazel, correct the Severity of that Frown, lest you should have more of the Medusa than the Medicis in your Face.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Saucy Jackanapes!

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: What, then I've quite lost my City Acquaintance; why, I've promised all my Friends Tickets for my Lord Mayor's Ball, through your Ladyship's Interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Interest indeed, for such a—

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P:
If Blowbladder-Street has any Charms—Sir,—Maam—Not a Step—The finest Gentleman! ha, ha, ha.—And what can you say for yourself, you cowardly ill-look∣ing Rascal (To Canto.) Desert your Friend at the first Pinch—your Ally—your Part∣ner—No Apology, Sir.—I have done with you. From Poverty and Shame I took you; to that I restore you. Your Crime be your Pu∣nishment. (turning to the Audience.) Could I be as secure from the Censure of this Assembly, as I am safe from the Resentment of Dupe, Novice, Squander; from the alluring Baits of
my amorous City Lady; and the dangerous Combination of my false Friend, I should be happy.

Q.L: 'Tis from your Sentence, I expect my Fate;
Your Voice alone my Triumph can compleat.
